headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Actually, the third quarter revenue was supported by smartphone growth. When I say smartphone, it's more than 16-nanometer. Of course, it includes 16-nanometer and also the companion chip that goes along to support a smartphone.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, so it's smartphone demand across different nodes.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: All right, the next question will be coming from JPMorgan's Gokul Harihana (sic) [ Gokul Hariharan ].

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: My first question is on HPC. I think you provided a rough estimate of $15 billion wafer revenue in 5 years. Just to get some granularity around that, is that the total market demand including IDM, fabless, everything? Or is it just the foundry opportunity within that market? Because as you mentioned, some of the segments have very dominant IDM players. Some of them, like GPU, are a lot more fabless.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: What I cited are the wafer revenue in terms of foundries revenue, but we -- many of our customer, fabless customer, wants to get into that market. And any product can be foundry-ed, by the way, okay? So we just play together in that sector. That's all, yes.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, all right. So would you say that server is still a big portion of that opportunity? Or you are not including the server opportunity, which is predominantly IDM, in that $15 billion.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Server is included in that opportunity.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, all right. Second question is on 7-nanometer. I think you mentioned about 15 customer tape-outs already ready for next year. Are there a significant number of HPC-related tape-outs there? Or the starting tape-outs are mostly high-end mobile in that 7-nanometer.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: There are a significant number of HPD -- HPC tape-outs. But in terms of volume, it will be high. Mobile product volume will be much higher in the beginning.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay. And maybe last one. I think you had mentioned, 10-nanometer, you'll have more than 70% market share. Any rough thoughts on 7-nanometer? Is it going to be 90% to 95%? Any early thoughts on how you think about the 7-nanometer market share?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: High. It's high.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Higher than 10?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: We want to do every node is higher than the previous node.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Next question will be coming from Credit Leone's (sic) [ Credit Agricole's ] Sebastian Hou.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Dr. Sun, my first question is on the packaging business, so InFO and CoWoS. If I understand correctly, that the TSMC will take full responsibility of the packaging of logic and memory, and my question is that how to split the yield issues of memory with the memory partners. And as this part of the business continue to grow in terms of revenue percentage and dollar amounts, and how do you expect this to -- will this increase the business risk for you? And how do you see that impact your risk yield and profitability?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: To answer your question, no, we don't have full responsibility, as you said, on the memory portion. Memory, we'll work with a memory supplier, but it's mainly their responsibility to make it reliable and fully functional and can be incorporated into InFO's technology. But we don't have the full responsibility, as you just mentioned.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, I think my question is -- sorry. I should have asked more clearly. So my question is, when the packaging, the -- for example, the -- a fail. The yield is not good, but you have to be responsible for that cost, including the memory cost, right?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: That's a good question. Once a part fail, which we don't expect too often, of course, but once that the parts fail, we trace it back. We work with the customer, identify whose responsibility is.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, so the yield rates is -- if you look at it like that, the yield rate problem is led by your memory partners, and that cost will be attributed to them but not you.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay. And my second question is a very simple one. Just I noticed that your 0.11- and 0.13-micron revenue increased quite a lot in terms of quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year in third quarter. Can you give us some piece and [ph] colors on what type of the application and products with that?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, on 0.11- and 0.13-micron, we -- as I mentioned, we developed some specialty technologies. And so I give you -- the one more major reason probably is some of the power management IC.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Next question will be coming from Daiwa's Rick Hsu.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: My first question is -- I think Lora was talking about your revenue CAGR in the next 3 to 5 year will be 5% to 10% per annum. I'm wondering if you could give us some ballpark number, if I want to break it down, of the incremental revenue increase across-the-board with your 4 demand drivers, that includes your HPC, mobile, auto and IoT. Could you give us some idea how -- the contribution from each category?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: I cannot. I think Mark said last quarter, in a 5-year time frame, half of our growth will come from the mobile, still; and about 1/4, of high-performance computing area. And the other 1/4 will be from IoT. That's the ballpark figure.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: All right. The second question is, I think this year your revenue growth is going to be pretty, pretty strong. [indiscernible] your 5% to 10% guidance. And that also increase the comparison base for next year, so if I want to ask for some color about your next year's growth, this is going to be a 5% to 10% range. Will you be -- will that be closer to lower end, or high end?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: I will not comment 2017 growth in this moment. You can just follow our indications. We still believe, 5 to 10 years, compound annual growth rate will be between 5% to 10%. Of course, some year will be higher. Some year will be lower, but this is our goal, to drive the compound growth rate 5% to 10%, okay?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: I think we will need to go to the line, first, before we come back to the floor for the follow-up questions. Operator, could you please have the next caller on the line, please?

Or when I think about it on a quarterly basis -- I mean you've talked a little bit about seasonality in large customers driving depreciation. I know in the past you've smoothed it a little bit as well in the first half by starting wafers. I guess I'm worried a bit about first half next year gross margins. Can they also still be close to 50% in kind of a seasonally soft period? Those are 2 my kind of clarification questions.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Steven, you talk so fast. It's even beyond me, so I really -- I haven't caught your first question quite well, but I think the second question, you want us to explain about gross margins for next year, right?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Primarily during the seasonally soft period. So in the first half of the year, can your gross margin still sustain about 50%, as you had suggested, I think for the full year?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Are you asking about 2017? Okay, yes -- it's...

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Correct. First half next year, in a seasonally softer period, can gross margin sustain 50%?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, I will not particularly comment on quarter gross margin outlook, but if you hear what I said earlier and -- in the longer term, we intend to keep about 50%. Of course, some quarter depend on the seasonality and utilization. They may kind of swing a little bit. And we have 10-nanometer, which will be a dilution to our margin as it comes on, but over and over, I think 50% -- about 50%, is probably a good direction, okay?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, let me just jump to my last, longer-term question. Midway through the third quarter, one of your competitors now, Intel seems to have rebooted their foundry effort. TSMC's been under attack many times in -- over the years. And you guys have done a great job with your scale, your tech leadership, existing relationships, your kind of customer agnosticism, if you will.  But I'm just curious, is there anything different this time with some of the competitive threats out there? Are you hearing any differences from a customer perspective or even from just a competitive perspective on pricing or incentives or just a general spectrum-ship [ph] that's going on right now? Any thoughts on competitive landscape this time around?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Steven, can you speak slower? Because really the bandwidth is very narrow, so only part of the spectrum was received.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: So Steven, if I understand you, maybe I can sort of summarize your very long question. You are just asking what's the impact to TSMC if Intel becomes very serious about foundry, right?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Well, they certainly have threatened in the last 90 days with a greater level of intensity, and so I'm curious if anything's different from a competitive landscape perspective this time around. In the past, you have done a great job fighting off competition. Do you see anything different this time around?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: We can intend to do a great job going to the future too.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Let's come back to the floor. Okay, follow-up question. First come from Crdit Suisse, Randy Abrams.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Last year, there was CapEx savings where the mobile products migrated, 20 to 16. And there was capacity conversion. Could you talk about the outlook for the 16 node, if you expect to backfill as some of the leading products move. Or you could see the same type of move of converting capacity from 16 down to 10 and 7. And is it efficient to make that capacity conversion?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: We fuel our capacity according to the demand, of course. And so the next year, we expect the customer move, especially the high-end smartphone, the move from 16 to 10. And then we expect the second wave and third waves of customer to enter into 16-nanometer. So, so far, we will convert some of the 16-nanometers capacity into 10. We will if the demand is not as high as it this year, okay? And you are talking about the converting efficiency. Quite high.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay. And so -- and when you're saying -- so your base case is no conversion. It's only a -- only on a demand disappointment that you -- like, your base case is you can fill that capacity, okay. The second question, you used to disclose IDM business every quarter. It's no longer in the quarterly, but IDM last year grew from 15% to 18%, so it's actually a reversal that IDMs grew as a percent of sales. If you could talk about that bucket, which it seemed like it continued to come down relative to fabless, but with some of the mergers, like NXP-Freescale, are you seeing as a result of that any change in outsourcing? Or for your overall IDM business, any change?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Did you say the IDM revenue growth is 18%?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: In the -- yes, in the annual timing, it was 18%. The year before was 15%.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: IDM.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: For IDM, yes.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: IDM outsourcing, or IDM?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Well, just IDM as your percent of revenue, like the total bucket of IDM.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: I see. We -- indeed our growth, more recent years, comes from fabless, also from IDM outsourcing and from system companies. As a matter of fact, in -- if I look at the recent histories, the growth fastest is from system companies, then the IDM outsourcing, then the fabless growth.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: If I can add, this year the number will be similar to last year.  Okay, next follow-up question will be coming from Citigroup's Roland Shu.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Just one follow-up question for your inventory level. I know your inventory is mainly from WIP and also finished goods. I have looked at these in 3Q. You have a 17% higher revenue compared to second quarter, but in your inventory there had been a decline about 10%. I agree, you said that you ship off as WIPs. However, at the end of -- in 3Q, you probably have much more wafer starts also. So that actually will be turned to the WIPs, yes. So I just want to understand, what is the percentage for your finished good in your inventory? Are you -- did you ship off these finished good to your customer in 3Q?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Simple answer is yes. We have very low finished goods inventory. If you understand our business model, that's the way it should be.  So a majority part of our inventory is WIP, okay? So what I'm talking about is the fact that it does help to reduce inventory because you don't need to build out earlier. So you can do pretty efficient, okay?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay. So can I ask how much cycle time you have been reduced in 3Q?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Actually, most of the cycle time reduction come from the manufacturing site. I'll give you one example. I cannot nail down that between the second quarter and the third quarter, but I'll tell you that, last year and this year, we probably improved by 20%. We shortened that cycle time.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, there are follow-up questions. First, from Morgan Stanley's Charlie Chan.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: So Mark, so a couple of weeks ago you announced that TSMC is going to kick off the 3-nanometer R&D, but that doesn't really show in your competitors from -- not even the 5-nanometer. So what does TSMC see that your competitors don't see in terms of technology breakthrough or any customers who is demanding for that 3-nanometer?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: I'm sure our competitors are working on it. So I just have the chance [ph] last week in TSIA annual meeting. I spelled out our 3-nanometer status. And everybody is working on it, I believe. At least the top 3 or 4, and a few in the pathfinding mode. And how to do the transistor, I think everybody is still searching it. It is not obvious at this point, but that is what's the researching is about. So we intend to invest heavily in the much forward-looking R&D, anticipating all kinds, both in the Moore's law scaling as well as the 3D IC integration. So we intend to fulfill the future system requirement this way; and to customize -- to fit our technology just for the future system requirement instead of a just so-called CPU cadence.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: So in your long-term revenue mix. So Lora just mentioned that, long term, your mix will be half from mobile, 1/4 from HPC, 1/4 from IoT. So what is it today? I mean the mix today from these 3 segments?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: We didn't separate the revenue on the way you describe. We just have Communication, Computer, Consumer, Industrial/Standard, which you can find from our management report, which a very big part is Communication. And the increasing important part is Industrial/Standard; Computer getting smaller, yes.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay, follow-up questions also will be coming from Credit Leone's (sic) [ Credit Agricole's ] Sebastian Hou.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: I have questions from -- more from the -- in terms of margin from the application perspective, so if you look at your future growth driver: smartphone, which is Mobile; and high-performance computing; and Automotive; and IoT. And Automotive and high-performance computing right now are still relatively smaller, but actually this part will be -- presumably this part, these 2 businesses, will grow faster. So in terms of the margin, will these 2 part of business carry higher than the other business margin? And how do you see this impact your margin? Will they bring more upside to your margin down the road?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Right. Lora just I mentioned we try to keep our 50 -- around 50% margin. Yes, of course, the higher the better. And we want to work on that, in fact, for our customers.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up questions on that is on your 7-nanometer, because you have 2 variants for mobile and high-performance computing platform. And do you see any margin or profitability difference between these 2 areas?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: At this point, it's too early to say. We're just working with our customers. The price changes year by year, so how that pans out is yet to be seen. I certainly hope the high-performance computing margin is higher than our mobile because I look at Intel's margin -- but we still at the same time want to enable our customer to enter that high-performance computing market, and that is a consideration. At this point, we do not assume major differences, but of course we work with our customer to get their margin high. And therefore, we benefit our margin too.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: All right, finally, the follow-up question will be coming from Deutsche Bank's Michael Chou.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: On the outlook by segment in Q4.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: Regarding the 16-nanometer market share, what is your expectation for next year versus this year? Will that be similar?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttext: It will be similar.
